contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox astronaut | name =Mirosław Hermaszewski | image =Miroslaw H.jpg | type = [[Intercosmos]] Cosmonaut | nationality =[[Poland|Polish]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1941|9|15}} | birth_place =[[Lipniki]]{{dn|date=September 2012}}, [[Wołyń Voivodeship (1921–1939)|Volhynia]], [[Reichskommissariat Ukraine]], [[Nazi Germany|Greater German Reich]] | occupation =[[aviator|Pilot]] | rank =[[Brigadier General]], [[Polish Air Force]] | selection =[[List of astronauts by selection#1976|1976 Intercosmos Group]] | time =7d 22h 02m | mission =[[Soyuz 30]] | insignia =[[File:Soyuz-30 patch.png|30px]] |}} '''Mirosław Hermaszewski''' (born September 15, 1941), is a retired [[Polish Air Force]] officer. He became the first (and to this day remains the only) [[Poles|Polish]] national in space when he flew aboard the [[Soyuz 30]] spacecraft in 1978. ==Early life== Mirosław Hermaszewski was born in Lipniki, [[Wołyń Voivodeship (1921–1939)|Wolynian Voivodship]] in the [[Reichskommissariat Ukraine]], in present day - [[Ukraine]]. He is a survivor of [[Massacres of Poles in Volhynia|the Volhynian massacres]] during [[World War II]], during which Ukrainian nationalists murdered 19 members of his family, including his father.{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} ==Intercosmos program== In 1965, he graduated from the military pilot school in [[Dęblin]]. In 1978, he was chosen from almost 500 Polish pilots to take part in the [[Intercosmos]] space program. Together with [[Pyotr Klimuk]], he spent almost eight days on board the [[Salyut 6]] [[space station]] (from 17:27, June 27, 1978 'til 16:31, July 5). During their time in orbit, they carried out [[geoscience]] experiments and photographed the Earth. They landed 300 km west of [[Tselinograd]]. He was awarded with the [[Hero of the Soviet Union]] title for that flight. ==Afterwards== During the period of martial law in Poland, Hermaszewski was a member of the [[Military Council of National Salvation]] (''Wojskowa Rada Ocalenia Narodowego'', WRON), a military quasi-government. Later, he was a commander of the Fighter Pilots School in [[Dęblin]]. In 1988, he was promoted to [[general]]. Between 1991 and 1992, Hermaszewski served as a second-in-command of the Headquarters of the Airforce. He is currently retired. Mirosław Hermaszewski enjoys [[science fiction]] novels, hunting, [[sailing]] and various other sports.{{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} He is married to Emilia Hermaszewska and has two children, Miroslaw (born 1966) and Emilia (born 1974). ==See also== * [[Zenon Jankowski]] ==External links== * [http://www.dqfilms.com/hermaszewski_eng.html Circumstances of space travel of the first Pole in a documentary by Maciej Odolinski] *[http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/international/english/hermaszewski_miroslaw.htm Spacefacts biography of Mirosław Hermaszewski] {{Authority control|VIAF=18493050}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Hermaszewski, Miroslaw | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = September 15, 1941 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Lipniki]]{{dn|date=September 2012}}, [[Wołyń Voivodeship (1921–1939)|Volhynia]], [[Poland]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hermaszewski, Miroslaw}} <!-- [[Category:Astronauts|Hermaszewski, Miroslaw]] too general --> [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:European astronauts]] [[Category:Polish astronauts]] [[Category:Generals of the People's Army of Poland]] [[Category:Polish pilots]] [[Category:Polish Air Force generals]] [[Category:Foreign Heroes of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cross of Grunwald]]
